statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description: Paul Pierce scored 21 of his 35 points in the third quarter as the Boston Celtics won their fifth straight game, 95-80, over the Denver Nuggets.
article.headline: Pierce propels Celtics to fifth straight win
article.linkText: With 21, Pierce outscores Nuggets in third quarter
article.story:
BOSTON (AP) -- Paul Pierce needed a little time to find his range against the Denver Nuggets.
Pierce

Pierce scored 21 of his 35 points in the third quarter and Antoine Walker added 28 to lead the Boston Celtics to their fifth straight victory, 95-80 over Denver on Wednesday night. Pierce outscored the Nuggets by five points in the third period as the Celtics extended a seven-point lead to 22. "Offensively, he's playing so well," Boston point guard Kenny Anderson said. "He's a great shooter and is definitely one of the top three scorers in the league." Boston is on its longest winning streak since taking six straight Jan. 23-Feb. 4. Denver has lost six of seven overall and six straight against Boston. "We don't have enough firepower to score enough," Denver coach Dan Issel said. Pierce was held to just four points until he banked in a desperation half-court heave as time expired in the first quarter. Pierce then scored Boston's first six points of the second quarter before breaking the game open in the third.
“ Our goal coming into the season was to make the playoffs. As the year goes on, it raises our goals to win the East and get homecourt advantage. But we've still got a long way to go. ”
— Paul Pierce
After Anderson's jumper gave the Celtics a nine-point lead early in the second half, Pierce scored 18 of Boston's next 20 points. Pierce, second in the league in scoring to Allen Iverson, hit a 30-footer as time expired in the period to give Boston an 82-60 lead. "Paul has really blossomed since he came into the league," said Raef LaFrentz, who played with Pierce for three seasons in college at Kansas. "His game fits the NBA style to a tee and from what I've seen this is just the tip of the iceberg for him." Pierce was lifted midway through the fourth with the Celtics ahead 91-72. The Celtics improved to 10-6, their best start since the 1991-92 season, when they were 14-6. "We feel like the East is wide open and there's really no dominant team out there," Pierce said. "Our goal coming into the season was to make the playoffs. As the year goes on, it raises our goals to win the East and get homecourt advantage. But we've still got a long way to go and we can't get too excited yet." Avery Johnson and Nick Van Exel each had 16 points for the Nuggets. Joe Johnson added 10 points and six rebounds for Boston. The Celtics took a 51-42 lead, their largest lead of the first half, on Johnson's jumper with 45 seconds left in the second quarter. Van Exel's 16-footer with 27 seconds remaining cut the halftime deficit to seven points.

Game notes
Celtics point guard Randy Brown got his first action of the season after missing the first 15 games with a strained groin. Rookie Joe Forte was put on the injured list with a right ankle sprain. ... Van Exel played despite a sore left elbow. He was traded to Denver on June 24, 1998, for Celtics center Tony Battie and the draft rights to Tyronn Lue.
